alert.note: Alert for Calabasas and Agoura Hills (California) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Fire Weather Watch issued November 06 at 2:50PM PST until November 09 at 6:00PM PST by NWS Oxnard
info.description: CORRECTED TO ADD CALABASAS AND AGOURA HILLS ZONES ...FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT FROM NOON WEDNESDAY UNTIL 6 PM THURSDAY FOR MOST MOUNTAIN AND VALLEY AREAS OF LA/VENTURA COUNTIES AS WELL AS THE MALIBU COAST DUE TO GUSTY SANTA ANA WINDS AND LOW HUMIDITY... .Another round of gusty Santa Ana winds and low humidities will impact portions of Los Angeles and Ventura counties Wednesday into Thursday. The gusty offshore winds will begin late Tuesday night or Wednesday morning, but the humidity levels will most likely not fall to critical levels until Wednesday afternoon or evening. While there is still some uncertainty in the strength of this upcoming Santa Ana wind event, there is at least a 50 percent chance of reaching Red Flag Warning durations from Wednesday afternoon into Thursday afternoon for the most wind prone areas of LA and Ventura counties. Elevated fire weather conditions are likely across wind prone areas of San Luis Obispo and Santa Barbara counties. ...FIRE WEATHER WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH THURSDAY AFTERNOON FOR GUSTY SANTA ANA WINDS AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY FOR CALABASAS AND AGOURA HILLS... The National Weather Service in Los Angeles/Oxnard has issued a Fire Weather Watch for wind and low relative humidity, which is in effect from Wednesday afternoon through Thursday afternoon. * WINDS...North to northeast winds 15 to 30 mph with gusts 30 to 40 mph. * RELATIVE HUMIDITY...Falling to 10 to 20 percent by Wednesday afternoon and evening, and 8 to 15 percent by Thursday. * Impacts...If fire ignition occurs there could be rapid spread of wildfire that would lead to a threat to life and property.
info.instruction: A Fire Weather Watch means that critical fire weather conditions are likely to occur in the coming days. Residents near wildland interfaces should prepare now on what to do if a wildfire breaks out. See readyforwildfire.org and wildfirerisk.org for information..
